I climbed Carstensz Pyramid with a team. We wanted to establish a new route and meet the local Dani people. We were warned about bandits, but we were not deterred. We reached the summit and were given a standing ovation.

Fashion is all around us, from clothes to home decor and accessories. Here are some fashion trends for this year.
Ned Ingham is a dress designer who creates beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He thinks people should avoid traditional, stiff dresses and opt for simpler styles instead. Ned has been drawing and designing dresses since he was a teenager and has the skills to make clothes.
Ned's designs aren't just for brides. He also creates elegant evening dresses with modern colors and fabrics. You don't have to be a bride to wear one of his dresses! He also designs classic suits that look new and stylish.
Sally Quail is a jeweller who designs unique pieces with large semi-precious stones. She used to work for an art dealer, but she decided to design her own engagement ring because she couldn't find one she liked. Now, her designs are popular among stars.
Lily Grimson is a handbag designer who creates beautiful, handmade bags in the UK. Her designs are full of glamour and are never ignored. She uses high-quality materials like calfskin and silk.
Peter Little is a hairdresser who has styled the hair of famous people for over 20 years. He wants his clients to have hair that looks real and easy to style at home. He charges a lot for his services, but he has also created his own hairdryers and styling equipment.
Penny Pratt is a florist who runs her own shop and provides floral designs for supermarkets and restaurants. She has no formal training, but she has won many awards for her simple and modern arrangements. She thinks the key to a good flower arrangement is to keep it simple, strong, and not too complicated.

The Merrion Hotel is a new, five-star hotel in Dublin. It's made from four old houses that have been renovated. The hotel has the latest technology to make it easy for guests and staff. The hotel's manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know each guest's name. To help with this, the hotel has a computer system that keeps track of guests' preferences. This system cost £250,000, but it will pay for itself in the long run, according to MacCann.
Guests can request certain music CDs and find them ready for them on their next visit. The hotel also has a system to control the room temperature, so guests can choose their own temperature. Business travelers will appreciate the hotel's individual rooms, which have all the necessary equipment for work, such as phones, fax machines, and video-conferencing facilities.
The hotel has also thought about the future and installed extra cables to handle any new technology that comes out. The TVs and DVD recorders can be easily updated. Despite all the technology, the hotel has made sure the rooms are comfortable and welcoming.
The hotel has many other facilities, including a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants. The chef, Patrick Guilbaud, has a Michelin-starred restaurant in the hotel. He has a new kitchen and better parking facilities. The hotel can offer his restaurant without taking on any financial risks.
With its technology and staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her garden is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants spread themselves around the garden, but she likes the way it looks. The garden has two long flower borders that are very colorful and well-organized. This is because the previous owners, who were good gardeners, left some plants behind, and Susan inherited a gardener named Danny. 
Susan likes to paint individual flowers, not the garden as a whole. She takes one flower at a time, paints it, and then brings another one in. Sometimes it takes a few years to finish a painting. Her busy time is in spring and early summer when the tulips and poppies are blooming. She likes the way they change shape and color over time.
Susan has always been interested in plants. She studied botany in school and used to collect wild flowers. She didn't like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. Now, she has plants from all over the world in her garden, and she likes them just as much. She lets her garden grow freely, like a happy aunt letting her children play. 
Susan has two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for, and she's been busy painting. She now has an extra gardener to help her, but she knows she needs to get her hands dirty to stay connected to her art.

Many trees were knocked down in the storms in March. The town's market square lost two big lime trees. This changed the look of the town centre, which made some people unhappy. Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the police force, was one of those unhappy people. But at the time, he was too sick to notice. He had bronchitis and was in bed for a few days.
Pelham's wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor, but he didn't listen. He thought the police force needed him and he couldn't take time off. This made him feel worse and his memory got foggy. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor's office. The doctor gave him medicine and told him to rest.
When Pelham felt a bit better, he asked his wife about the damage to their house. She told him that the walnut tree in their garden had been knocked down. He didn't think much about it at the time. It was only when he got out of bed on Saturday that he noticed how much the garden had changed. The tree used to hide the worn-out furniture in their living room. Without the tree, the room looked bright and the furniture looked old and worn out. The house next door, which was hidden by the tree, was now visible and looked ugly.
Pelham didn't like the new view. He thought it was terrible. His wife, Molly, disagreed. She thought they needed to buy a new sofa to make the room look better.

We had been living in our valley for 16 months when we realized that the hills surrounding our home could pose a danger to our safety. The winter came early that year, and the snow started falling heavily. The snow blocked our lane and made the path slippery and dangerous. We were worried about the river, the Ryburn, which was normally calm. We remembered that if the snowmelt had not been controlled by dams, the river could have flooded our valley. The snow started to melt, and the river began to swell. We watched as the clouds gathered over the hills, warning us of an impending disaster. The river became wild and turbulent, and we were worried that it would overflow. For the first time in years, the reservoir overfilled and water poured into the stream. The river was furious, and the stream beneath our bridge was deeper and more turbulent than we had ever seen it. We prayed that the dam would hold, and fortunately, it did. The waters subsided, and we were relieved. Thanks to the dam, we can now enjoy the power of the river and feel safe in our valley.

I'm Mark Adams, a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. I've been doing this job for 10 years. Before this, I did some reviews for other newspapers, magazines, and radio. I met Tom Seaton, the arts editor, who also worked for radio and TV. He hired me, but he wasn't a journalist, so he might not have chosen the best people for the job.
At first, Tom's idea was to have a team of critics who could write about different art forms like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would meet for lunch every week to discuss what we would write about. But it didn't work out like that. We didn't get together as planned, and everything was done over the phone. People didn't like the idea of a critic writing about different things. So, I focused on film.
I like my job because I get to write about one film each week. I wouldn't want to write about every film that comes out. That would get boring. I get to make my own arguments and choose what I want to write about. I don't think I have to be right or wrong about a movie. I just need to give my opinion. I'm not a judge, and I don't want to be one.

Do you know why a 17-year-old girl would want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? It's because she loves it! She's looking for a training partner who likes long-distance running, swimming, and cycling. She wants someone who can do all three without stopping. The triathlon is a popular sport that people watch and participate in. But why do athletes do it? Melanie Sears, a 17-year-old triathlete, doesn't say it's for personal satisfaction or mental challenge. She just loves the feeling of finishing.
Melanie started triathlons at 14 and won the junior section. She was so confident that she entered the National Championships, but things didn't go as planned. She got lost during the cycle ride and ended up cycling 20km too far. She was disappointed, but she didn't give up. She wants to keep going and is determined not to stop.
Melanie's coach, Steve Trew, is impressed with her determination. He says she works hard and never gives up. Melanie was the top junior in the European Triathlon Championships and finished 13th overall. She wants to improve her cycling skills and is trying to convince her parents to buy her a new bike so she can participate in longer races.
Melanie's training is intense, and she doesn't have much of a social life. She spends most of her free time training and talking to her teammates about their times and achievements. She wants to enter even tougher events and is looking for someone her age to train with.

I love collecting things and many people do too. One in three adults collect something. Collecting is a world of passion and excitement. But remember, only collect things you really love. People have been collecting things for a long time. Even ancient people collected stones and shells because they liked their shapes and colors. I have been collecting things all my life. I collect flowers, pottery, and paintings. My first collection was of stones I found in my parents' garden.
I was lucky to go to a school in a remote place in England when I was six. My parents would take me to the local museum, which had many objects collected by people in the past. I was fascinated by these objects. Many people collect things, not just me. Some people collect because it's the only thing they can control. For me, it's just something I enjoy.
There are many famous collectors, like the Duc de Berry in France, who had a room full of strange and interesting things. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. But you don't have to be rich or powerful to start a collection. I have collected many different things, like tulip bulbs and china cups. I even collected 350 American rag dolls. Unfortunately, my house caught fire and my collection was destroyed. I was very sad.
What I find interesting is how collections change hands. A spoon that once belonged to a king or a famous poet can be very valuable. When certain objects become popular, their price goes up. The toys of the 1950s are now valuable if you still have the original boxes. (I threw mine away, along with the toys!)

"My job: Four people talk about their work.
Lisa - Science Museum Exhibition Coordinator
I organize temporary exhibitions at the science museum. I plan and design the exhibition and advertise it. I read about the subject and talk to experts to decide what to show and how to show it. I make sure visitors can understand the exhibition by planning interactive activities and workshops. I also work with engineers to make sure the exhibition is safe.
Janet - London Taxi Driver Teacher
I teach people how to drive a taxi in London. I check the accounts and prepare materials for students to learn the routes. In the morning, students practice finding the best routes. I help when they disagree about the best way to go. When they're almost ready for the test, I give them a new route and tell them why they can't take the original route because of road closures. This helps them think critically.
Sarah - Marine Conservationist
I work from home and respond to phone calls, create educational materials, and organize courses. Sometimes I go to our main office, but mostly I work by the sea. I also work with schools and study centers, teaching people who make decisions about the ocean. I take them on boat trips to show them the importance of marine life. I love my job because it's my hobby too. The only downside is that we need more money, so I have to find more resources.
Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher
My job is varied. I make sure our books meet customer needs and keep track of our stock. We have high standards for information and content. We get many letters about issues like boundary representations, which require careful answers. I discuss projects and sales with other publishers. I work with a friendly team, which makes my job enjoyable. The only downside is too much administration, which takes away from more interesting tasks like product development and design."

We always go to Ireland in June. We've been going to Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim for 14 days every year. The house is big and near the sea, close to the village of Ardbeag. We found out about the house from a friend, Strafe. He saw an advertisement and showed it to us. We didn't like our previous holiday because the food was bad. We've been friends with Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me (my name is Milly, but my friends call me Milly) for a long time. We all live near each other and are about the same age.
When we arrived, Mrs Malseed was waiting for us in the big hall. She always knows when we're coming. She showed us to our rooms, which were named after flowers. In the winter, she takes care of the little things, like painting flowers on the doors. Her husband, Mr Malseed, takes care of the repairs and decorations.
When we got to the hall, Mr Malseed greeted us with a big smile and said, "A hundred thousand welcomes!" He made us feel like we were more than just hotel guests. We all smiled and felt like our holiday had started. Nothing had changed at Glencorn Lodge, everything was fine.
After dinner, we played cards for a bit, but not for too long because we were still tired from our journey. There were other people in the lounge, including a man and a French couple. We could see some of them walking on the lawn or going down to the beach. The next day, we would walk along the beach to Ardbeag, have coffee, and come back for lunch. In the afternoon, we would go somewhere else. This is what we usually do because we love the beautiful landscape here.

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex who works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden chalets. Sarah graduated from university last summer and is doing this job for a year or two before settling down.
Sarah's day starts at 7 am. She walks to the chalet, makes her own breakfast, and then prepares breakfast for the guests. They have a big breakfast with lots of food. After breakfast, Sarah cleans the rooms and makes the afternoon tea. She usually goes skiing in the afternoon and comes back to the chalet to prepare dinner. She serves dinner at 8 pm and then clears away the dishes.
Sarah likes to chat with the guests, but sometimes they want to be alone. She meets her friends in the evening and they go out to bars. But on Sundays, Sarah works early and has to make breakfast for the guests who are leaving. After they leave, she cleans the chalet and does some shopping. She then prepares tea for the new guests who arrive at 4:30 pm. Sarah helps them with their ski gear and then has dinner and maybe a drink later.

Miss Rita Cohen, a small, pale girl, came to Seymour's factory one day. She was wearing overalls and big shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. Despite her young appearance, she claimed to be six years older and was studying at the University of Pennsylvania. Seymour sometimes helped students who wanted to learn about the leather industry. Rita was interested in every detail, asking questions like "How many pieces come in a shipment?" and "How do you make the leather?" Seymour liked her enthusiasm and offered to take her on a tour of the factory.
Rita asked about the tannery, where the leather was made, and Seymour told her it was an old industry that had been around for thousands of years. He offered to take her to the tannery to see how it worked. Rita had never seen anything being made before, except for her mother making a cake when she was a child.
Seymour was impressed by Rita's eagerness to learn and decided to show her the whole process of making gloves. He asked her what size she wore, and she said she didn't know. He offered to make her a pair of gloves from start to finish.

Chris Arnot talks to four people with dream jobs. Are their jobs as wonderful as they seem?
A. Raquel Graham is a personal assistant to a pop star. She loves her job, but she doesn't like flying. She takes sleeping tablets to help her relax on long flights. When she's not traveling, she does paperwork and organizes the pop star's schedule.
B. David Brown used to be a golf caddy. He liked his job, but it wasn't easy. He had to carry heavy bags and deal with bad weather. Now, he works as a statistician for a golf tournament.
C. Martin Fern is the editor of a newspaper's food section. He loves his job because he gets to try new foods and drinks. He thinks it's okay for restaurants to charge high prices if people can afford it.
D. Dick Prince is a children's book writer. He started writing 20 years ago and has written many books. He likes to write in the morning and spends a few hours typing out his ideas. He gets a lot of letters from readers and tries to answer them all.

There was an old building in the lumberyard by the lake. It was used to store wood and sawdust. One afternoon, the boys were bored and decided to go up to the roof. Michael, the leader, said, 'I dare you to jump down!' and he jumped first. The others followed, laughing and having fun. After a while, they got tired and went back down. But Michael stayed on the roof, hesitating. He was scared to jump again. The others started to get impatient and called out to him to come down. Michael was too afraid to move. He stayed on the roof for a long time, feeling embarrassed and ashamed. Finally, he jumped down and walked home, feeling sorry for himself. When he got home, his stepmother was upset with him for being late for dinner. Michael was still feeling sad and ashamed, and he didn't want to talk to anyone.

Are you unhappy in your job but don't know what to do? Many people are in this situation. One good option is to see a careers adviser. They will ask you to write about yourself and then do some tests called 'psychometrics'. The results will show which careers might be good for you and what training you might need.
I went to Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. The tests were like my science exams. I had to answer questions quickly with a group of people. It wasn't about passing or failing, just about understanding myself better. Then I talked to an adviser and they gave me a report with their ideas and suggestions. I agreed with most of it, but I was surprised to find out I didn't do well in the scientific and practical tests. 
It's not always necessary to change your job completely. Donna Laney, a 25-year-old, lost her job as a marketing manager after five years. Her friends suggested she go to Career Analysts. She was surprised to find out she had a talent for design, but it was expensive to retrain. In the end, she used her existing skills to move to a job in public relations.
Some people have had very positive experiences with careers advice. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services and decided to change her job. She took tests and had four sessions with an adviser. The tests showed she was interested in sciences, and she decided to study geology.
However, careers advice isn't always helpful. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, went to a careers adviser but didn't find it useful. She didn't like the ideas they suggested because they required a lot of retraining or a pay cut. She thought she could have gotten the same advice from a friend.

'Going to the Dentist: A New Experience
Imagine walking into a dentist's office that looks like a modern art gallery. You'll see bright paintings on the walls and a comfortable blue couch where you can sit while the dentist checks your teeth. Dr. Jerome, the dentist, wants to make you feel relaxed and comfortable. He says many people are scared of going to the dentist because they associate it with pain. So, he has created a friendly atmosphere to make you feel at ease.
Dr. Jerome doesn't wear a white coat, which is unusual for a dentist. He thinks it can make people feel nervous. Instead, he wants you to feel relaxed, interested, and even enjoy your visit. He uses special techniques to make you feel calm, like virtual reality headsets that let you watch a film while he examines your teeth.
The dentist's office smells nice, like a perfume shop. Dr. Jerome wants you to feel like you're in a pleasant place, not a scary dentist's office. He takes his job very seriously and uses the latest techniques to make sure you have a good experience. For example, he uses a special instrument that sprays warm water to clean your teeth, instead of scraping them.
Dr. Jerome went to the United States to learn new techniques and found that making patients feel comfortable makes it easier for the dentist too. He wants to change the way dentists work in the UK and make it a more pleasant experience for everyone.'

Chocolate is a popular treat that comes from South America. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter, which is a lot of money. In fact, eight per cent of all chocolate is bought at Easter. Christmas is the only time when people eat more chocolate. 
Chocolate has been around for a long time. The Aztecs, Toltecs, and Mayans grew the cacao tree over 3,000 years ago. The fruit of the tree contains 20-40 seeds, which become cacao beans when dried. These beans are used to make chocolate. 
In the past, the Aztecs used cacao beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water'. They flavoured it with spices and drank it on special occasions. The Spanish liked it better with cinnamon and sugar. 
In the 17th century, chocolate houses were popular in European cities, where people would gather to drink chocolate. Until the 19th century, chocolate was made from solid blocks that had to be melted in hot water. Then, a Dutch inventor created chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter. 
In 1847, a British company called Fry and Sons created the first chocolate bar. Later, a Swiss company added milk to the recipe, making milk chocolate. 
Today, British chocolate companies like Cadbury are popular, but some farmers who grow cacao beans are struggling because of a price crash in the 1980s. Maybe we should think about them the next time we eat a chocolate bar.

Peter Cooke is 83 years old and has become very good at making things out of shells. He started doing this 10 years ago and has been perfecting his skill ever since. He shows me his work in his apartment and is very enthusiastic about it. He has had two exhibitions in London and people like his work a lot. Some of his pieces are very expensive, but he doesn't care because he loves making them.
Peter used to want to try other things like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he is happy to keep making shell objects. He has his own special way of doing things and uses materials he finds. He even travels to different countries to find beautiful shells.
Some people might think Peter is taking too many shells from the beach, but he says he only takes dead shells and doesn't harm the living creatures. He thinks it's okay to collect shells that are already empty because the sea breaks them up anyway.
Peter is very proud of his work and hopes that people will continue to like it. He wishes he had started making shell objects earlier so he could have made even more beautiful things. Despite this, he is happy with what he has accomplished and is excited to see what the future holds.

Kira Langer is a 15-year-old model. When she's not traveling to beautiful places and appearing on magazine covers, she's studying for her school exams. I went to meet her at her modeling agency. The receptionist told me Kira would be late, which made me a bit worried. But when she arrived, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologized for being late. She was with her mother, who was proud of her successful daughter.
Kira doesn't wear expensive clothes, just a simple black dress and trainers. She's very friendly and seems normal, not selfish or vain. She's surprised by her new fame, which happened unexpectedly. Her older sister encouraged her to enter a modeling competition, and Kira won easily.
Now, Kira has to manage her two lives: school and modeling. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some people at school are mean and say she has a high opinion of herself. Kira says this isn't true; she's just more confident now and can stand up for herself. As a model, she can't make plans with her friends because she might get a job at short notice. But her friends understand.
Kira has a bright future ahead of her, and she's still studying for her school exams. When I asked her what she would do if she wasn't a model, she said she would like to be a journalist, like me.

Terence and his son Chris are on a big adventure. They are searching for gold in Africa. They have been searching for 10 years in a mountain in Wales. They think they are very close to finding a big vein of gold worth five million dollars.
Terence, who is 68 years old, is an explorer. Chris is a mineral expert. They have been digging in the Welsh hills for years. They have found some gold, but they need to dig a little deeper to find more.
The father and son team have spent all their money on their search for gold. They need to find someone to give them £50,000 to help them dig deeper. They are hoping to find someone who will believe in their dream and help them find the gold.
The people in the town where they are searching for gold are excited about the possibility of finding gold. They hope it will bring more tourists to the area. But some people are worried that if they find gold, many more people will come and damage the hillside.
Gold mining used to be a big industry in Wales, but it has declined a lot since the 1880s. Now, some individuals are starting to search for gold again. George Hall, another prospector, is planning to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill. He says searching for gold is exciting and emotional. He hopes to find some gold this time.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves to spend time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry at Southampton University. When she's not teaching, she goes on underwater adventures in a special vehicle that's like a small car. She dives down to the ocean floor to study underwater volcanoes.
The space inside the vehicle is very small, so she can touch the two pilots who are with her. They have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. The dive can take 16 hours - three hours to get down, 10 hours to collect samples, and three hours to get back up.
If something goes wrong, she can press a panic button. The outside part of the vehicle will break off and float to the surface quickly. Rachel has gone on six dives so far. Last year, she went on a trip with a Russian team to a place with many underwater volcanoes. They were studying how the ocean floor changes.
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the university. She teaches to earn money so she can continue her research on underwater volcanoes. She loves her job and finds it exciting to explore the deep ocean.
Rachel has been studying underwater volcanoes for three years. When she finally saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling. She felt a sense of wonder and excitement being at the bottom of the sea, knowing that no one else had ever seen these things before.

I was tired, hungry, and dirty after my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired from all the traveling, and my mind was overwhelmed by all the new languages, timetables, and currencies. I said, "I'll never do this again." But I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. The good thing about Inter-Rail was that I could travel anywhere in Europe for a month with just one ticket. This way of traveling is special because it lets young people see many countries in a short time. On my first trip, my friends and I didn't know how much we could travel. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in France. But then we started to explore and discovered that we could travel to many other countries without extra cost. We were not very interested in culture, but we liked the freedom to organize our own trips. We were excited to see new places and do things our own way. When we arrived in a new city, it was like discovering a new world. Seeing Europe with my own eyes was a great experience. It's one thing to know about a place, but it's different when you see it for yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos are boring - they don't show the real experience. The train trip was a valuable experience for me, and it helped me understand how big and diverse Europe is.

Losing your luggage at the airport can be very frustrating. You might have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline finds your bag. This can be especially bad if you're in a different climate or far from home. Airlines don't usually say how many bags they lose, but it's a common problem. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes.
The airline's baggage system has a few flaws. They have to check you in early so that your bag can get to the plane on time. They also have to allow some extra time for your bag to get from one plane to another. But sometimes flights are delayed because of security checks or air traffic. This can cause problems with your bag.
Human error or accidents can also happen. For example, the label might get torn off. This can happen more often at big airports where many bags are being handled. Even good airports like Amsterdam or Singapore can have problems sometimes.
To avoid losing your luggage, try to take a direct flight and check in early. If you have to change planes, try to fly with the same airline. Give yourself extra time by taking an earlier flight and make sure your bag is clearly labeled with your home and holiday addresses, and the flight numbers. If your bag still goes missing, go to the baggage hall and fill out a report before leaving the airport.

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer who loves kingfishers. These birds are blue-green and live near streams and rivers, eating fish. The kingfisher's home is a special place with old trees, soft greens, and browns. The sunlight creates many different yellows, making the scene look soft and peaceful. The bird flies quickly and quietly, like a laser beam, leaving a lasting impression. Charlie fell in love with kingfishers when he was young, but he can't explain exactly why. Kingfishers are famous in stories and myths. In Greek legend, a moon goddess turned into a kingfisher. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body turned blue and its lower body got hot from the sun. This is partly true. Kingfishers don't have blue feathers, but the way their feathers are structured makes them look blue. This is why the bird can change from bright blue to green depending on the light. Kingfishers are popular among wildlife photographers because they are beautiful and can be easily watched from a hiding spot. Charlie's first hiding spot was an old blanket, and he took his first good picture of a kingfisher after four years of trying. Kingfishers became his passion, and he spent all his free time near a stream with many kingfishers. However, he had to miss school, which affected his grades. Despite this, his love for kingfishers got noticed, and he started working as an advisor for a nature magazine. He now works as a freelance wildlife film cameraman and wants to make the perfect kingfisher film. He wants to show the beauty of the bird through pictures, without using words. Charlie is still fascinated by the kingfisher's colors and spends a lot of time thinking about them. His photos show how much he loves the bird, but there's more to his relationship with the kingfisher than just his work.

Giving directions to an orchestra is not an easy job. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
A. ANNE MANSON Anne Manson is a 30-year-old conductor. She worked with a famous conductor, Claudio Abbado, in Vienna. She was asked to help with an opera and then became a conductor herself. She is not nervous when she stands in front of an orchestra.
B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE Andrew Constantine is a 31-year-old conductor. He won a big competition and got many performance opportunities. He is still trying to get rid of the "competition" label.
C. WASFI KANI Wasfi Kani is the founder of Pimlico Opera. She loves the long practice period before an opera performance. She started conducting in her late twenties and learned from a good conductor named Sian Edwards.
D. ROGER VIGNOLES Roger Vignoles is a 48-year-old conductor. He used to work as a musician and then became a conductor. He was surprised but enjoyed conducting a Handel opera from the piano. He is happy to take on new challenges.
E. WAYNE MARSHALL Wayne Marshall is a 32-year-old conductor. He was noticed by a famous conductor, Simon Rattle, and started conducting a musical in London. He is not afraid to tell the musicians what he wants. He has not studied conducting formally but people have been kind to him.

**Theme Parks in Britain**
If you're thinking of taking your children to a theme park, there are many to choose from in Britain. We asked five families to try out the best ones. Here are their experiences:
**Fun Island**
We went to Fun Island with our three-year-old child. We thought it might not be as exciting as a big theme park in the US, but we were surprised. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World.

People love dolphins. They are smart, friendly, and seem to understand human emotions. We see them in movies and TV shows, but did you know that their situation is very serious? According to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, their numbers are decreasing rapidly.
Dolphins are found in the oceans all over the world. There are many different kinds, but some are more common than others. The striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the harbour porpoise are all found in European waters. Some dolphins live far out at sea, while others live near the coast.
Unfortunately, many dolphins are in danger. The number of harbour porpoises in the North Sea has decreased by up to 89,000. This is because of pollution and overfishing. Dolphins need to eat fish to survive, but if there are no fish, they will not survive. They can also get caught in fishing nets and die.
Another problem is that dolphins can eat poisonous substances that are in the water. These substances can build up in their bodies and be passed on to their babies through their milk. This has already happened to one young dolphin.
Finally, dolphins are also affected by noise pollution. They use sound to communicate with each other, but loud noises from ships and other machines can disturb them. We don't yet understand how this affects them, but it could be a big problem.
Overall, dolphins need our help. We need to take care of the oceans and protect these amazing creatures.

It makes our muscles stronger and helps us look better. It also helps us feel better and sleep better. Exercise can even help us feel less stressed and anxious.

We should start slowly and carefully, especially if we're new to exercise. It's also a good idea to talk to a doctor before we start a new exercise routine.
Good posture is important too. If we stand or sit up straight, we look and feel better. We can practice good posture by imagining a balloon pulling our head up towards the sky. This helps us lift our chest and stretch our stomach, making us look slimmer.
Stretching is also important. It helps us move more easily and prevents injuries. We should stretch four or five times a week to stay flexible and strong. A good exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, a workout, and a cool-down. By following these steps, we can stay healthy and fit.

Ice Skating: A Fun and Healthy Activity
Ice skating has a long history. People used animal bone skates thousands of years ago. In Scandinavia, skating was important for the upper class. In the past, skating was a fashionable and elegant activity. However, in the 1920s, a young girl named Sonja Henie changed the way people skated. She introduced a more athletic style, and this made skating more popular.
To start ice skating, you need to be balanced and controlled. Your body position is important. Keep your legs slightly bent and your knees slightly bent too. This will help you stay balanced. It's also important to relax while skating. If you're tense, you might fall.
To get started, stand with your heels almost touching and your feet pointing outwards. Move your back foot forward while making a small movement with your other foot. This might seem easy, but it takes practice to get it right.
Even experienced skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, try to relax and roll with the fall. To get up, get into a kneeling position and then stand up.
There are different types of ice skating, such as figure skating, free skating, and speed skating. To start, it's best to learn figure skating and then move on to elementary free skating. Most ice rinks offer lessons and guidance to help you learn.
To improve your skating, practice regularly and do exercises to loosen up your legs, back, and shoulders. This will help you stay relaxed and flexible. Skating is a great way to improve your balance, coordination, and overall health.

As a result, people became shorter and weaker. In one study, scientists found that when people started eating corn, they became sick and underweight. 
But now, some countries like the US, Holland, and Japan are eating a more varied diet again. This means that people are getting taller again. The average height in these countries is now 179-180 cm.

WE LOVE ANIMALS My family and I love animals. One day, my daughter found a beautiful pine snake. She asked if we could keep it. I said yes, but only for one night. We have a special tank for animals that pass through. I was running late, so I quickly boiled some water. When I got home, my sons were screaming for help. Domino, our cat, had caught a mouse and was running around the room. I tripped and fell, and then I saw the snake. It had escaped from its tank and was slithering around the floor. The cat, mouse, and kids were all running around, and the snake was hissing and striking. I was worried, but I finally managed to catch the cat and free the mouse. The snake was very strong and hard to handle. I sat on the floor, rocking back and forth, and eventually the snake relaxed and let me pick it up. I took it to the garden and let it go. It slid up my shoulders and settled there, like a warm blanket. We stood there in silence, and then my son said, "You're nice and warm, Mum, and the shed isn't." I got the kids to help me encourage the snake to move on. It slowly went up the wall and disappeared over the roof. When it was gone, my three-year-old son said, "Wow, that was a big snake!"

"Every week, British newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break their own rules. Although some famous people sometimes take pictures with the paparazzi, this is not common. Usually, people in the public eye are hurt when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, few people ask the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) for help. The PCC was created to deal with these kinds of issues. Rarely, if ever, do these pictures serve the public interest. Do pictures of famous people help to solve a crime? How did a famous actress's hotel room picture protect public health and safety? The actress had a good reason to complain, but she didn't. The PCC should investigate this and other cases.
One idea is for the PCC to take the initiative and stop these shameful attacks. This could lead to many newspapers being punished. This would be reported by other newspapers and on TV and radio. The public would not support it, and editors would have to stop publishing these pictures. Photographers would also be affected, as they would no longer be able to make a living taking pictures of celebrities. However, there are many problems with this idea. How would the PCC decide whether to investigate a case? Should it ask the person involved to make a complaint? And what if they refuse? Celebrities and royalty might expect the PCC to investigate any story about them, and then be upset if it doesn't. The PCC's role is too big. How could it monitor all British newspapers, national and local? There is also the problem of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy has been invaded, they might not want the added embarrassment of an investigation. Many people just want to move on with their lives. A few might have other reasons for staying quiet. They might have a worse story that they have kept secret, and they know that if they complain, this story could become public too. Even the PCC might become the enemy. A British comedian was also a victim of the press when his honeymoon was secretly photographed. He didn't complain then, and not even when his family was again photographed on holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper would run the pictures again with a new story about his anger. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It's hard to see a simple solution to this serious problem."

I took over my family business when my father was ill. I was scared and became a bit too bossy. I thought confident people were like that, but I learned otherwise. To be confident, you have to believe in yourself. If things get too hard, I don't feel guilty if I do things tomorrow. When I'm scared, I tell myself I have nothing to lose.
C. Lisa
People think I'm confident, but I'm actually very nervous. I had to learn to look confident because it's important in TV. Interviewing people made me realize that everyone gets nervous in important situations. The best advice I got was from my mother: "Who's looking at you? Everyone's too busy worrying about themselves." I also learned that you gain confidence by doing things that scare you.
D. Barbara
My confidence comes from enjoying my work. I've built it up over the years by learning from my mistakes. If you just get on with it and learn from your mistakes, you'll be more confident next time. I work hard and like myself, not trying to be what others expect.
E. Kim
After college, I worked as a secretary and was too scared to speak up in meetings. Eventually, I found the courage to speak up. When I started working in politics, I was nervous and would shake. I told myself, "Don't be silly. People do this every day." I also wrote down some points to refer to. I think everyone is a little nervous when speaking in public. The secret of confidence is telling yourself, "Nothing is impossible."

Paul Forster went to a kite-flying festival in Malaysia. He met a man named Adnan Ali, who gave him a kite as a gift. Adnan said, 'You have to keep it. It's a tradition. If the string breaks, the finder gets to keep it.' Adnan showed Paul his collection of kites. They were all the same size and made of paper and bamboo. They sat in the shade of some tall trees and looked out at the festival. There were 10 platforms with helpers holding up kites, and people waiting to fly their kites. When the whistle blew, the kites went up in the air like rockets. Over 500 people had signed up for the competition, which lasts for five days. Each person had made four different kites to be judged on how they looked, how stable they were, and how well they flew.
Adnan invited Paul to visit him at his home to learn how to make kites. Paul accepted and went to Adnan's house. They drank tea and ate snacks in a big room. Adnan told Paul to come back the next day to help him rebuild his kite, but Paul couldn't. Instead, he went to explore the state of Kelantan. He drove to the mountains and took a wrong turn, ending up at a river. A boat took him across, and he saw a sign that said 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km'. He walked up the path and met a man named Baba, who ran a small camp. Paul decided to stay there for the night. The next morning, he woke up to a beautiful view of the mountains. In the afternoon, it started raining. Paul got wet and worried about his car getting swept away. But everything was okay, and he was back in Kota Bahru, the capital, where everyone was friendly and asked him questions. Paul remembered Kelantan for its kind people, not just its kites.

What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but we're all different. Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.
A. Melanie, 22, dancer - I love shopping! I spend as much money as I can. When I have cash, I go shopping and don't get sad.
B. Brenda, 40, office manager - I don't like shopping. My husband does most of the shopping because he cooks. I take my kids to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it.
C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager - I only shop for things I really need. I don't like shopping and would rather do something else.
D. Anita, 35, TV producer - I like to go shopping sometimes, but I know what I want and don't waste time.
E. Lizzie, 41, secretary - I don't like shopping at all. I hate buying clothes because I can't find what I want. I usually get my clothes from others.
F. Lisa, 22, actress - I'm a happy shopper! I go shopping with friends and sometimes buy things on impulse.
G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant - I'm a careful shopper. I like going shopping, but I don't buy much. I sometimes shop to cheer myself up, but it doesn't always work.
H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker - I love shopping, but only on certain days. I'm a careful shopper and look for good deals.
I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager - I don't like shopping. I work in the city centre, so I don't find it exciting. When I have to shop, I just get what I need and don't bother trying things on.
